column4: Question: How do I get the last command issued from the history?
Question: How do I get the last command issued from the history, from a shell script, without using UP Arrow
Question: How do I get the last command issued from the history, from a shell script, without using UP Arrow or .bash_history?
what is the problem you're trying to solve?
you can get the last thing *typed* - history | tail -1
When users issue certain commands I want to capture them instead of executing, with something like an alias that runs a script
... capture them?
you want to make certain commands do something else, basically?
Yes, to intercept potentially harmful commands like rm *
what would you want to do with them, afterwards?
No, email it to an administrator with whoami and date
and pwd also
okay. The simplest answer is "you can't"
It is easy to alias rm to run a script that executes various commands, I just want to capture the command the user entered in that script.
okay. you can get the parameters of a script with "${@}" inside it.
but I think you should probably look at a restricted shell.
Yes I can get the script arguments, but the alias script wasn't getting the original command as an argument, so I wanted it from history.  I think renaming the rm binary will work
it will, as long as nobody finds out what rm has been renamed to :-)
1) Please don't repeat a question
answer the first time then. don't be a jerk

2) If they don't appear automatically, you can use 'killall gnome-panel' to force it to reload. If it doesn't appear then, the application you installed doesn't add a menu item. Add one yourself with Applications -> Accessories -> Alacarte menu editor
3) Being rude will not get you *any* answers. Calling people a jerk is being rude, as is repeating your question. This is a busy channel, please do not add even more noise to it.
